Early Access Review

Boy where do I start? I think I've clocked a good 100+ hours on this game, so believe me when I say, that I do not regret a single bit of it. Roguelands is currently in Early Access as you may already know, this means that there are plenty of new and exciting content that is yet to be implimented in the game, with that said, I do indeed love indie games as much as I love the next.

From what I've noticed during the gameplay there are couple of pros and cons that are to be pointed out, though many other reviews have probably already covered it:

Pros    Fairly simple mechanics to work with
A variety of unique recipes
Multiplayer feature is always a plus
Cons    Bugs, though there are literally bugs in the game but I'm talking coding wise
Since the game is in an Early Access state, much of its content is yet to be released
The death penalties (this one is just my opinion cause I'm an angry player :P)
With all that's been said, sure there are plenty of other indie games that are like it e.g. Terraria and Starbound, both of which are pretty great indie games to kill some time on but even then each game has its own special features which keeps the game interesting, keeping in mind that Roguelands is indeed still in Early Access, it is a given that the game is bound to have bugs and it's up to community to spot such problems in order for Roguelands to progress and become a better game. I recommend that you should try a friends copy if not buy one yourself and support the developer as well :D

I hope this review helps in regards to your choice of purchasing Roguelands or not.

EDIT
Initially the game was perfectly fine until the developer released a couple updates, which caused for an abundance of bugs to appear, which you'll notice in the forums. I did recommend Roguelands in its previous state, however, there are just one too many bugs to deal with the current build, that it'll throw your gaming experience for Roguelands in shambles. I do not recommend playing the game as it is at the moment or another option is to test the waters of Roguelands and report your bug findings yourself.

EDIT 2
So at this point in time, I've clocked almost 300 hours on this game. Everything is a hella lot more stable now, plus there have been an abundance in updates with new items, misc, npcs, etc. since my last review update. Nevertheless, after all this time, I'm still enjoying this game as a solo player but I enjoy it the most when you muck around with friends in multiplayer. The ultimate weapons and armor update piqued my interest the most because your favourite weapon or armor can get reskinned with better stats. Roguelands is a definite go to indie game if you're looking for a fun, moderately fast paced game to play with friends.

One negative aspect of the game that has bothered me the most so far, is that the save files aren't saved onto a server, it is local based, meaning you can't take your character and ship progress with you, should you decide to play from another pc.

EDIT 3 (This one is more of a personal opinion from a Roguelands player standpoint)
Now that I've hit the 300+ hours of gameplay milestone, it is safe to say that bugs will be there until the full release but even then, should there be updates for new content, expect bugs. Not every player are the same in terms of playstyle, preferences, thought process, etc. I thought that I'd get bored after 300+ hours, at one point this was true but then I remembered that there is A LOT OF CONTENT yet to be released, as matter fact, Sean still have plans for new Combat Chips" which I'm definitely looking forward to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Picture this: You're transported to a mysterious planet with three fellow space cadets, sent to retrieve that last rare resource from the plants that reside within so as to create the mythical weapon of your dreams. As you arrive, you are greeted with an army of wild beasts ready to rip your bones from your body, and the planet itself seems like it's trying to destroy you.
You fight your way through horde after horde, mining ore and collecting resources along the way, all of you barely scraping through as you narrowly avoide the swiping claws and chomping jaws of your enemies. You all make it to the top of the world, out of reach from those below you, but barely alive. You pass around the last health potion each as you ration out your supplies and prepare to harvest the plant in front of you.
Finally, you and your fellow space cadets are ready, and move to harvest the flora, before hearing a mighty, bloodcurdling roar that seems to echo all around you. The four of you turn around to see a gigantic, shadowy figure hurtling towards you, appearing almost as big as the planet itself.
You ready your weapons, let out a battle cry of your own, and charge towards the fierce beast.

Roguelands is an incredible 2-D multiplayer rogue-like RPG set in space except not always in space and most of the time on foreign planets rather than space itself.
Did that grab your attention? Great, because it gets better from here.

If you played Magicite (an earlier game from the same developer; Sean Young), then you will feel right at home with the combat and the controls in general. However, Roguelands still brings fresh, new experiences and features to the table that not only offers great new content, but also enhances the already simple-yet-fun style of Magicite.
If you haven't played Magicite, then so long as you've played basically any 2-D platformer before, then you're sure to feel comfortable as the style is very close to home, and it will not take you too long to develop a feel for the controls.

Roguelands offers perma-death, as any rogue-like will, and features procedural generation of worlds, as any rogue-like will. Obviously, this is not an easy game, and you are certain to die time and time again, especially at the start of your Roguelands experience. So if a challenging game is not for you, then do not bother with it.
Roguelands also offers 4-player online multiplayer with a drop-in/drop-out feature to allow seamless interaction between players. I must say, as much fun as this game is, Roguelands truly shines when you're playing with your friends, and makes the experience all the more enjoyable.

The game is only in early-access now, and does not have an extravagant amount of content, but it has so much potential, and is an incredible amount of fun nonetheless.

Gameplay: 7.9/10 (Lost points as it is still buggy at the moment, but this is Day 1 of public release at time of posting - expect this to rise as the game progresses.)
Graphics: 8.5/10 (The 2-D nature is very enjoyable and pleasant to look at it, and is nostalgic with a touch of modern design making for a great mix.)
Soundtrack: 8.5/10 (w.Flux has done an amazing job on the music, and really captures the wild, unpredictable nature of the various worlds in the game.)
Overall score: 8.3/10 (It's only in its very early stages of development, but holds an amazing amount of potential, and is a lot of fun even now, despite the various bugs that are present.)

Thanks for reading!
~RedMasta

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If this early access build is any indications of what's to come, then this is one game to be looking out for. The developer has taken everything great from his first game and expanded upon it in this new space age style rogue RPG.

The combat system has been given a sleek new look with its own combat screen and skills menu, which gives fighting monsters some added intensity.

Additionally the foraging mechanic has been amped up by the introduction of droids or bots which harvest resource nodes for the player. This seems like a little change, but speeds the pace of the game significantly as you now have the option of multitasking which has been unseen in the likes of many other similar themed games.

Related to the foraging, the crafting is vast and will leave you itching to find out what other combinations you can make.

The visuals are stunning and gorgeous, and the music is beautifully composed and matches the beauty of the scenes. This is almost unheard of in early access indie games and is a great treat.

Although this game has many Pros, it does have its downsides. I can see the gameplay becoming stale after a while, much like its counterparts, but I believe that just comes with the genre of these games.

The game can be frustratingly hard and leave you feeling cheated with some of the current enemies and environmental hazards. Not to mention it is a bit of a pain to play with friends, but that is to be expected with an early access.


Overall, Roguelands has great potential and will bring you hours of fun, whether you are exploring by yourself or playing with your friends. Two thumbs up!

Edit: On a more serious note though, the developer(s) (I'm really not sure whether it's a small team or just one man, so excuse my ignorance please) are constantly bringing more, and more content incredibly frequently via updates to the game.

The game is a fun rogue-like experience, yet the use of being able to store your items in a HUGE chest which stay there even after death (the only things you lose upon death are the items on you at the time) makes this game a lot less frustrating than you may expect it to be, as you keep a lot of your things. A lot of people may be glad about this, while others, who are looking for a more serious rogue-like game, will probably find it too easy for a rogue-like genre of game, but my personal views on the matter are mixed. Without the chest, you would be able to replay the game from the beginning and have a different enjoyable experience every time, while it being more of a classic rogue-like game. Whereas the usage of the chest means that you can 'complete' the game ('complete' meaning get the best gear possible as there is no 'end game' per se) a lot easier than if there were no chests, meaning the game will last a lot shorter amount of time overall. However, dying does delete your character, meaning that you have to make a new one and start from level 1 again and gain all of your stats back.

The last thing I want to touch on is the fact that you are able to build your own ship... well, customise your own ship. It's a very basic, yet fun, addition to the game which allows you to make loads of cool rooms where you can add more machines or hang the badge/poster/photo things that you can receive from killing enemies - even bosses - on the walls of your ship (it's a rare drop but looks like a sort of photo of the creature in a frame which you are able to place on the walls in your ship or sell for a hefty price. Pretty neat).

The developer(s) are going in the right direction with this game and it's updates; they are always adding new weapons, armour, biomes and bosses for the user to battle - making the game a lot more fun and giving the player many more things to aim for with each update.

8/10 - Better with friends, but still a heck of a lot of fun on your own (and a lot more challenging).

So here's my review of what i've experienced so far in contrast to Magicite.

Ok so the game has quite a few changes to cover and i now have a much higher understanding of the game i feel i can explain them well.

Crafting is no longer done on the fly but is instead done on board your ship. After you succesfully complete each level you go to a safe level where you can buy items using credits, store items on you and either teleport back to your main ship or carry on going. If you go back to the ship you can craft new emblems to get new gear and use the alchemy station to combine items for health packs, mana packs, stamina packs and droid fuel (droid fuel is currently useless).

There are different tier emblems and when you combine 3 different emblems of the same tier (tiers 1-4) you can get new armours (helmet, torso and shield) new weapons (staves, gauntlets, guns, cannons, swords and lances) or new droids (look different but do the same in build 0.4.6).

To get these emblems you combine 10 of the same item (10 flutterflies for a flutterfly emblem for example).

So essentially the first planet you're on is for gathering every resource you see and cautiously killing everything launched at you to level up and get more powerful. The further into the game you get the better gear you get but each biome can gradually get harder. Desolate canyon being the easiest imo and hollow cavern being the hardest imo of the 3 currently playable.

That's all for now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Me and my friend have probably spent over 20 hours playing the game total, and we regret none of them (other than the ones spent before the reset). Roguelands has the platforming of Cave Story (except the platforms themselves are much more simpler), the RPG elements of Realm of the Mad God, and the action-adventure of The Legend of Zelda.

Pros:


+Fast paced, filled with action and fun
+Gameplay is interesting
+Simple yet fun mechanics
+The game lets you head in your own pace; you don't need to do worlds or anything in order
+Game is beautiful, background is always fitting and sprites look fantastic (for its style)
+Soundtrack and SFX are memorable (for the most part)
+Variety of items, weapons, armor, characters, etc
+Easy to level up and get nice gear (for the most part)
+Addicting
+Rewarding
+Risk for reward (Although I wouldn’t recommend risk)
+Challenging (in the fun sense)
+Lots of replay-ability


Neutral Factors:


=Better in multiplayer, but fun all the same in single player
=Deaths are permanent; you lose all character held items on death (might be a good factor for replay-ability)



Cons:

-Huge lack of a story
-Worlds are obvious re-skins
-No changes in the terrain whatsoever
-Barely any mobs in each world (3-4 at most, 5 if you include bosses)
-Game is a little glitchy at times
-A.I is a bit poor
-Repetitive at times
-Items (out of your inventory)
-Will sometimes spawn/float out of your reach
-Grab range is decent, but something could be done with your bot to grab items



Overall, this game is great, given its Alpha stage. It shows a lot of potential and shows a lot of development being put into it. The game is even updated every Thursday, so that might get you to play the game even more. This game is definitely worth 10 dollars, or even your 10 dollars.

9/10, I strongly recommend this game to anyone who was a fan of Magicite should play this.

From the constant support handed to us by the developer, with the never ending replayability and challenge this game offers, Roguelands is without a doubt one of the noteworthy games for all roguelike fans.

However, once getting a hold of the very comfortable control scheme and crafting system, you start learning the real challenges Roguelands has to offer. The game offers plenty of constantly updated planets that progresssively get much more difficult. Once you feel like you have a firm grasp of the difficulty, Roguelands offers to increase the difficultly to 3 more times whilst offering better loot if you're willing to sacrfice some in-game currency. This adds tons of reason to wanting to keep playing. However, no matter how many hours you pour into one character, death is inevitable, but there is alwasys something to learn with each death..
Although, this game obviously runs into some bugs, and many balancing issues I feel need to be worked out, it does not handicap the overall amazing experience you will get from Roguelands for just $10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Roguelands is a multiplayer 2D RPG. It has platforming elements much like Magacite but still manages to be satisfyingly unique. Developed and published by SmashGames we all knew we were getting into something fun and exciting. This game seems highly influenced by his previous game, Magacite and you can definitely see that. Sean, the developer of SmashGames, states he has not abandoned his first game, Magacite and in fact will be updating the game just as soon as Roguelands reaches version 1.0. Sean continues to update this game weekly and will be for a long time, he keeps his buyers up to date with information on the upcoming patches and can be easily accessed just below the page on Steam. Currently the game is priced at £6.99/ $10.00 and will presumably stay at this price. Hosting servers either requires: LAN IP addresses, Hamachi or other 3rd party programs or port forwarding. There might be other ways of creating severs but so far these are the only 3 I have found. Be sure to check you can do one of the above before purchasing this game to play with friends.

Enough of that, let me tell you the pros and cons about the game. Let me start out with the positives. So far I have played this game for 15 hours, I can see myself playing it for longer as it is just really enjoyable. This game is more fulfilling on your own but I have had a great time playing it with my friends as well. It offers a lot of different options to make your play style unique to the other players around you. The game has several different races to choose from, every player starts with the first one and by doing different things through your play through's you can unlock other races. Each race has 2 or 3 stats that it's dedicated to, weather it be dexterity and magic or strength and faith. All of these offer different weapons some using melee, others using ranged attacks including magic. Then the different weapons in the game also increase a specific stat and getting a prefix on the item can increase this set stat. Each stat has gives you a different weapon strength is a sword, dexterity a gun, magic a staff ect. For example, the Aether Blade which is a strength and dexterity based weapon gives you +1 Strength and +1 Dexterity.  I really like this mechanic and it was slightly used in Magacite but has been massively progressed in Roguelands. When you luck out in this game it is incredible, weather it be if you get yourself T4 legendary armour from a mystery box or if you ship droids give you a high level emblem. It has awesome art and design, the style of the game makes you want to keep coming back as it is just harmlessly addictive. It is very fast passed so you're never bored and it gives you non stop rewards. It offers lot's and lot's of replay-ability and combined with it's beautiful sound track, you can try not to, but you'll always come back for more.

However, every game must have it's bad side. Roguelands so far is not a hard game, the initial challenge can be slightly hard to get a grip on but as soon as you learn game mechanics the game becomes very easy and starts too become repetitive, grindy even. There are several different worlds for you to explore on your own or with friends but most of them just feel like re-skins of the other worlds and code seems to have been taken from Magacite. When playing on your own the game requires a bit more skill as the damage of enemies and the swarms of them can become overwhelming, this can result in a quick death. But if you've learnt how to play and dodge (q and e) then the game becomes a lot simpler and it can be quite easy for you to make your way to the end within an hour. When playing with friends, assuming you stick together, the worlds are very easy and the challenge of fighting off the enemies get's taken away as you have a lot more fire power and the enemies, so far, don't seem to scale with players and damage. That was a massive disappointment for my friends and I because there was no real skill required. After achieving level 30 the game becomes very grindy, but not in an exp sense. I made it all the way too level 99, level cap, and that didn't take a long time, 2-3 hours maybe. However what is grindy is the resource you need to collect to create weapons and armour, I think it is a good idea for the player to collect resources but when crafting gear and weapons you will want the higher stats and if you just get common tier this can result as being very irritating. Going back and forth for resource just to get an uncommon/ rare/ legendary prefix. That is like much other Rogue-likes so I don't really see it as a problem but for some people it might be. As for bugs, the game seems to be okay for bugs so far but there are a few things you need to know. If you are on multiplayer and are in the middle of a world and the host quits without saving all character progress for the other players get's deleted and only the host keeps his profile. When finding this it was very irritating and my friend and I had to recreate our characters and start again, although we were very quickly carried because exp is shared equally. If you wish to kill yourself to unlock new characters you will lose your battle chips (small bonus' and abilities that use mana) however, you can just drop them too your friend and they will give it back to you. That is a bypass and personally I don't think it should be available.

I rate this game a 7/10, with more development this game would offer a lot more entertainment and could easily make it's way to be one of my favourites. I could see myself playing this for hours if there was just a little more content.

Early Access Review

If you are looking for a nice hardcore adventure game, don't buy this game, it's not worth buying now. But if you just want to support its development, buy it, and it won't disappoint you.

Since there are already enough appreciations on this game, please let me talk about the negative sides. My friend who played Magicite with me recommended this game, and I bought it right after I saw the store page. But after spending half hour on this game, I feel I'm totally deceived. The store page doesn't show much content--I understand since it's early access--but the game has even less available content than the store page shows.

Please notice that I'm not complain about the game itself. Roguelands is awesome: it has awesome graphic, awesome music, awesome crafting and awesome difficulty. However, at present, this game has VERY LITTLE CONTENT and is far from playable. Till this review on 9-11-15, Rouguelands only contains 3 charactors and 3 playable maps. The whole playable content can be covered within 10 minutes, and the giant worm is the only challenging monster. There are lots of things to craft and the crafting system is amazing, but it's meaningless since there's no place for you to use them.

The good thing is, its developer(s?) is working hard, and releases update weekly. To be honest, I don't know why this game is on the Steam store page now, but since it's already there and it does have potential, let's just wait and see what happen next.

Somewhat confusing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing through this game with a friend for every version since Sean released it for Kickstarter backers at the very beginning, and I have to say though it looks very similar to Magicite, it really continues to build off that excellent game. Sean has been super great as far as regular updates to the game and responding to feedback from the community. So buying it in early access, here's what I like about the game so far.

What I love:
►Challenging gameplay. You need to play smart and careful if you want to survive.
►Cafting system. No recipes to memorize, rewards experimentation rather than memorization.
►Better multiplayer. Magicite was a lot of fun in multiplayer, but had many bugs with syncing, enemies disappearing, warp glitches. Things have been much more stable in Roguelands.
►Roguelike but also persistent. The way the game works is that each character you create only has one life, however you can bank items on your ship to be used in future playthroughs. The plan is also that you'll unlock new classes, races, and abilities as you play as well (not implemented as of v 0.4.6 though so can't really say much on that).

That's all for now, can't wait to see where development goes for this, but I have been very impressed with the quality and responsiveness in each update so far.

3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you liked Magicite, you will love Roguelands. Yeah I groaned at how generic the title is, too, but then I played it and time flew by and I was reminded of how special and fun Magicite was. But don't get it twisted, Roguelands is definately its own game.

Now this is fairly early access, so while there is totally a playable game, some elements in-game are placeholders (its that kind of EA, for those that are familiar). There is supposed to be one update a week.

Essentially, you have a base that is a ship where you can store stuff from your adventures. On the ship, you can also craft, upgrade stuff, and chat with other people. You gear up and venture off onto planets to go on missions to level up and find stuff. One thing I always love, which is present here, is permadeath with meta-game building elements. Upon death, you lose what is on your character, but not what you smartly stored on your ship. This totally adds in that risk/reward kinda stuff.

Pros:
+Gameplay is sooo addicting, similiar to Magicite. When you first start its hard-as-nails, and then you slowly learn enemy tells and such, and get better.
+Artwork, music, and sound effects are very polished, and look gorgeous.
+Lots of items and mechanics to learn, even at this point.
+Character creation allows for many different builds to play the game with (three major ones at this point, which is enough, but plenty more are coming from what the other icons on that menu state).

Cons:
-Some of the stuff like post-level loot chests are not finished yet (I am excited!!).
-No controller support which everybody whines about, but honestly, I don't think it would be good for a game like this (lots of mouse aiming).
-Its very hard. You have to enjoy learning, as in all good roguelikes/lites.

Yeah this is totally worth it. I will get tons of hours out of this - they probably should have charged twice as much, even in early access.

If you're familiar with Magicite, Roguelands will be very familiar. The art style and gameplay share similarities, but there are also major differences. These differences, however, are so unique, that the game stands on it's own and in many ways, it's an improvement. In the game you play as a 'space cadet' of your own creation, via a character creation system similar to Magicite. Earth has been destroyed by humanity's carelessness and you're now floating around in space in your ship exploring the universe. Immediately, you'll notice differences from Magicite. You no longer craft on the go, but instead everything is done on your ship. The emblem system allows you to now craft and save equipment on your ship for later plays. To gather the necessary resources for said emblems, you have a collecting robot that follows you around and gathers resources for you. Like Magicite, you aim with your mouse and move with the WASD keys. However, unlike Magicite, you now use number keys as hot buttons when you want to perform an action. Want to collect a resource? Aim at it and press 1 to send your little robot to go get it. Attacking is also a bit different, as you now switch between exploration mode and attack mode with a right mouse click. Overall, this is an improvement to the crafting system as collecting resources is not only easier and smoother, but crafting means not losing items right away if you die.

However, the difficulty is also greater here. You no longer have the ability to craft on the fly, as mentioned, so whatever you go in with, you're stuck with. Just as well, there are now greater dangers. Not only do you contend with tough enemies, but you must also contend with some large environmental hazards, as large meteors and rocks fly from all directions. This is actually more frustrating than fun. While fighting enemies, which are often challenging enough, you must also contend with these rock hazards. At times, it becomes impossible to avoid damage, and with such limited health, you can find yourself quickly dying. As you progress, you gain the ability to craft greater equipment, but getting there is an uphill battle. Many times, as fun as the game can be, it gets frustrating. Suffice to say, if you can't handle the punishment of challenging rogue likes, this isn't a game for you. But if you enjoy them, or you were a fan of Magicite, you will find a fun game here.

Overall, this is an improvement to the crafting system as collecting resources is not only easier and smoother, but crafting means not losing items right away if you die.

However, the difficulty is also greater here. You no longer have the ability to craft on the fly, as mentioned, so whatever you go in with, you're stuck with. Just as well, there are now greater dangers. Not only do you contend with tough enemies, but you must also contend with some large environmental hazards, as large meteors and rocks fly from all directions. This is actually more frustrating than fun. While fighting enemies, which are often challenging enough, you must also contend with these rock hazards. At times, it becomes impossible to avoid damage, and with such limited health, you can find yourself quickly dying. As you progress, you gain the ability to craft greater equipment, but getting there is an uphill battle. Many times, as fun as the game can be, it gets frustrating. Suffice to say, if you can't handle the punishment of challenging rogue likes, this isn't a game for you. But if you enjoy them, or you were a fan of Magicite, you will find a fun game here.

Rougelands impliments the good aspects, and a few bad ones but its early access so Ill let it slide, of Magicite mixed with a very Sci Fi feel. The Crafting system is much better in my opinion though the grindy ness of emblems is a bit annoying but not unbearable and the storage across character is very nice. If you are looking for a rogue-like game though this isnt fully that. Yes there are Rogue-like aspects of the game and yes if you die you lose all your progress and have to restart but it also feels like a normal RPG just with higher consequences. The game isnt finished and during me and my friends 4 hours run of the game we did notice alot of bugs mainly boss issues and areas that werent finished. Over all it is a great game for Early Access and if you enjoy rogue-likes or RPGs this is a great game to pick up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Roguelands is a 2D sidescrolling RPG. The combat, while similar in appearance to games like Terraria and Starbound, offers a layer of depth in the form of weapons with specific limiters. Each of the currently available races start out with a different, distinct weapon: Wanderers have a sword that swings in a typical arc, Centurions with a sword that only jabs forward, and Royalites with a wand that shoots out slightly delayed projectiles, while other weapons are currently obtainable through the game's crafting system. Assumedly, future races will also feature their own special weapons.

The game itself was surprisingly difficult with constant environmental hazards complementing enemies with otherwise simplistic attack patterns forcing us into dangerous situation while leveraging the limitations of our arsenal. There's lots of resources to collect, which is then fed back into crafting tables back at the players' hub.

At the time of writing this it is Build v.0.4.6, and right now the game is VERY Early Access
date:
with many zones still barren/under construction. From our experience last night, it seems that only a couple of the areas have enemies/resources fully implented, but, if the current content works as a clear indicator for how future zones are going to be designed, I have high hopes for this one.

TL;DR The game's pretty cool but it's early access so don't buy it expecting a 100% finished game. DO buy it if you want to participate in the game's development or if you want to try it now and pick it back up in a year or two.

Also, v0.4.7 is slated to release today at (hopefully) 5 PM EST. ( https://twitter.com/SeanYoungSG/status/664803713270304770 )

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a good mix of old arcade games where if you die, you lose everything and a mix of new age where you can save items in storage between games. I love that it becomes easier with multiple people playing, but it is also possible to play it easily in solo mode. You can customize the layout of your ship the way you like and there are many different places to explore and learn. As you play you get chances of getting stuff when you die depending on what you do. It is really fun and has lots of playability.
